author: mariusvanderwijden
content:
Back from vacation, immediately with my first question:
Stumped why this test should pass, code `6000e0000000` seems to have some unreachable code to me (three STOP instructions in a row
```
./eofdump eofdump -hex 0xef00010100040200010006030001001404000000008000016000e0000000ef000101000402000100010400000000800000fe
Header
-----------
EOFMagic: ef00
EOFVersion: 01
KindType: 01
TypesSize: 0004
KindCode: 02
CodeSize: 0001
Code 0 length: 0006
KindContainer: 03
ContainerSize: 0001
Container 0 length: 0014
KindData: 04
DataSize: 0000
Terminator: 00
-----------
Body
-----------
Type 0: 00800001
Code 0: 6000e0000000
Section 0: ef000101000402000100010400000000800000fe
Data: 
```

author: chfast
content: The `e0` is `RJUMP` followed by 2 bytes of immediate value. Then you have single `STOP`.

author: _shemnon
content: That's one reason I wrote a pretty printer.  I always look at my validation errors in pretty printed code.
